utterance: Greeshma Gadikota: So I have a question that is perhaps a little more fundamental. So in the context of trying to actually capture CO2 from air, there is the enthalpy contribution which is trying to bind the CO2 to the surface and then there's the entropic contribution where we can effectively engineer a substrate so we can lock the CO2 molecule into that particular pore space. In the context of direct air capture, how important are entropic contributions like in terms of the energetic input, should we even does it even make sense for us to think about engineering materials for from an entropic capture point of view or does it simply make sense for us to just think about trying to engineer the enthalpic component of it. That is so I wasn't sure what the current thinking is along those lines.

annotations.ask question: The speaker is explicitly requesting information or clarification on the importance of entropic contributions in direct air capture and the current thinking on engineering materials from an entropic capture point of view.
annotations.identify gap: The speaker mentions not being sure about the current thinking on the matter, indicating a recognition of her own lack of knowledge.

utterance: Chris Jones: I think the conventional wisdom in the literature thus far has focused on enthalpy because it is more straightforward and tractable. I think there is good science to be done by looking at the entropic contributions and I think that area is less explored.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on existing ideas by providing insights into the literature and research areas.
annotations.identify gap: The speaker identifies an area less explored in the literature, which is the entropic contributions.
annotations.offer feedback: The speaker provides a perspective on the importance of entropic contributions, which can be seen as feedback.

utterance: Jarad Mason: Yeah I mean I think you pay a really large entropic penalty for CO2 going from being free in the gas phase to confined on a surface and so if you can do anything by inducing an increase in the entropy of a material when it binds CO2 to kind of compensate for that then you can favor the absorption of more CO2 and potentially reach higher capacities at these lower partial pressures. But like Chris said I think it is a very unexplored kind of area. It's less obvious to me I mean usually the enthalpy and entropy of absorption should be quite highly correlated because the more stronger the binding site you have for the gas the more constrained it is going to be on the surface and so there's usually not that much you can really do which is why maybe it makes sense just to focus on binding energy because the entropy is just going to kind of tag along. But that's where I think if you have more dynamic adsorbents or sorbents and things that respond and are not just inert materials but actually change in terms of the dynamics or structure as a function of CO2 partial pressure then you open up opportunities for thinking about engineering entropy.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on existing ideas by discussing the role of entropic contributions in CO2 capture and its implications.
annotations.identify gap: The speaker recognizes an area of research that is unexplored, specifically engineering entropy in CO2 capture.

utterance: Greeshma Gadikota: Thank you.

annotations.acknowledge contribution: The speaker is verbally recognizing another group member's input without agreeing or expanding.

utterance: Chris Jones: I think a lot of classical adsorbents if you go to textbooks right are solid rigid materials where the entropy of adsorption on the surface at different sites is not terribly different. But a lot of the dynamic materials whether it be the moffs that you're familiar with Jared from your past history or solid ionic liquid hybrids, supported liquid phases, polymeric structures that have chain mobility, those are all things where you can engineer the entropic term such that you have very different entropies of adsorption.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on an existing idea by providing more details and examples regarding the entropic contributions to CO2 capture, specifically comparing classical adsorbents with dynamic materials.

utterance: Greeshma Gadikota: So from a big idea basic energy science point of view does it make sense for us to start thinking a little bit more systematically about how we can engineer or if there are limits to that entropic term what might those limits be. If there are correlations obvious correlations with respect to enthalpy what might those relationships look like. Are there limits in terms of performance in these unconventional solvent sorbent type systems that we can now start to quantify or maybe try to get a handle on. I think it seems like a rich area for computations as well as for experiments.

It's something that has been done in say you know flow batteries where we've done some work but lots of other areas too so that might be that might be an area that's ripe for some computational work.

utterance: Chris Jones: Can I ask a question based on that because a lot of the computational material screening for separations that I'm familiar with leverages the fact that people work with primarily crystalline materials that allows for this high throughput screening to be more effective. If we're talking about materials where we want to look at entropic terms there's a higher likelihood that we're going to be dealing with amorphous domains and I and I not being a computational scientist I'm less aware about how amenable those types of materials are you know less crystalline materials to these sort of high throughput techniques.

utterance: Pratik Dholabhai: I would agree with that. We might predict a structure but it might seem pretty much garbage at that point. So you know and that's why a lot of those screenings and throughput chemistries are run through as you exactly said more you know systems where we have better control we understand them better. utterance: Chris Jones: So I think we have about 15 minutes left and I want to try one other idea to stir some some different thinking. You know in a lot of engineered systems you have control over temperature pressure other parameters. One of the challenging things about direct air capture is you know we're we're stuck with 400 ppm CO2. But one of the things I haven't seen discussed a lot is if you imagine deploying direct air capture in different places around the world you could imagine having conditions that range from say minus 20 to 40 degrees C. So if you were asked to try to do something with CO2 at 400 ppm at minus 20 degrees C how would you think about doing that differently from you know the ambient conditions that we're normally used to thinking about indoors 25 degrees C you know 30% relative humidity. And similarly if you were designing a process that could operate in you know Oman in the middle of summer you know you you might be dealing with 35 40 degrees C ambient temperatures. So I just throw that out there as a way to maybe stir different ideas. This is a challenge where we're going to probably have 10 or 20 or 50 solutions that might be customized to different locations around the globe. So would you change your way of thinking if you were stuck working at minus 10 C or or 40 C? So I'll just throw that out there as a possible question.

annotations.process management: Chris Jones explicitly mentions having a limited amount of time left and aims to discuss another idea.
annotations.encourage participation: Chris Jones asks for others' thoughts on approaching direct air capture under different temperature conditions.
annotations.propose new idea: Chris Jones suggests considering the impact of various temperatures on direct air capture as a new perspective.

utterance: Greeshma Gadikota: Chris my short answer to that is absolutely yes. So we've been looking at pathways to couple direct air capture with carbon mineralization specifically with the intent of trying to produce carbonates and one way to do that is to use conventional sorbents that are cheap so you could use amino acid solvents like sodium glycinate or even MEA and so you have a high concentration of carbonate ions that you can now react with your calcium or magnesium produce calcium magnesium carbonate have sufficiently high hydroxyl ions so you can regenerate your solvent. So you have a one pot process with internal recycling internal pH swinging. So that's so that really drives down the cost of capture and mineralization but it needs higher temperatures because of the thermodynamics of CO2 sorption because we're trying to couple sorption and crystallization. This is a process that would not work in very cold climates like if we're trying to do this in the arctic there simply is not going to be enough thermodynamic driving force for that. There are other approaches to couple mineralization so for example again if you're trying to feed CO2 to an algae pond depends again where that algae pond is going to be located if it's going to be located in a temperate region versus in a really cold climate. So cold climate is a real challenge and I am not entirely sure what subset of solutions can be deployed there but if you but I do think there are a set of solutions that can be deployed in more temperate and tropical regions. So that's my two cents on the thinking and we do a lot of thinking around this space so I'd be very keen on hearing what we can actually do in really cold regions.

annotations.propose new idea: Greeshma Gadikota introduces a specific approach to couple direct air capture with carbon mineralization.
annotations.develop idea: She expands on her proposed approach, detailing materials, process, and conditions.
annotations.identify gap: Greeshma Gadikota identifies a challenge for deploying solutions in very cold climates.
annotations.encourage participation: She invites others to share their thoughts on solutions for cold regions.

utterance: Jarad Mason: I'd say from the perspective of like microporous adsorbents I think it's probably the opposite for just conventional absorption processes in that colder climates are probably a lot easier than hotter climates just in that in designing you can design binding sites that have much lower affinities for CO2 and still be able to achieve very high selectivities just because you have less thermal energy available so the Boltzmann distribution is going to favor CO2 going to you don't need as large of a delta E between different gas molecules to drive a lot of CO2 into a material. As the regeneration piece though that's less clear to me exactly how that changes. I think selectivity and capacity are a lot easier you can have weaker binding sites but whether or not that actually leads to benefits on the regeneration side when you're already colder I'd have to think a little bit more about. I guess if you're in a cold climate but you had some geothermal heat source or something readily available then you that might offer a lot of advantages.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on an existing idea, providing details on how microporous adsorbents could work in different climates.
annotations.ask question: The speaker poses a question about the implications of their idea, particularly regarding regeneration in cold climates.

So you might have to change the whole architecture to have something that is basically not solvent dependent like hopefully it's all immobilized and everything is just ionic without like a flowing solvent. So that's a really good question actually. It's a really good context for electrochemists to explore. I don't know if ionic liquids might be the best electrolyte then because they have a bigger range I don't know what their phase transition is.
